race.name: BADLANDS
race.tagline: 800km self-supported through Spanish deserts and 3,400m alpine passes. Where ultra-endurance meets extreme heat.

vitals.registration: Limited entry, sells out. Cost: ~200-300 EUR
vitals.aid_stations: None—self-supported. Resupply at public establishments only.

climate.primary: Extreme Spanish summer—desert heat to alpine cold
climate.description: August in Andalusia is brutal. Desert sections reach 40-45°C (104-113°F). Pico Veleta at 3,396m can drop to 5-10°C at night with potential freezing. 30-40°C temperature swings in a single day. Afternoon thunderstorms in mountains possible.

terrain.primary: Desert gravel, alpine passes, technical trails
terrain.surface: ~60-70% gravel roads, ~15-20% paved, ~10-15% technical MTB trails. Sand, loose rock, and dry riverbeds (ramblas) throughout.
features: Pico Veleta (3,396m—highest paved road in Europe)

logistics.explanation: Registration opens for exactly 5 days in November with demand exceeding spots 5:1. Granada provides excellent access via multiple airports, but self-supported format means managing 100km+ desert stretches with zero resupply. "The event organisers had agreed with a cafe in Gor to open for 24 hours for the riders, which proved to be invaluable," Bradley notes about the strategic support points.

length.explanation: 800km with 126-hour cutoff across Andalusia's three desert systems. Rob Britton notes "Badlands is won almost as quickly as it starts" with winners arriving Tuesday morning, while Bradley Shenton's buddy reported "the first three hours were ridden at 4w/kg, for a 750km race." The relentless pace from Granada to Capileira separates ultra-endurance specialists from weekend riders.

technicality.explanation: "This iconic climb is only 700m in length but has an average of 15% and a maximum gradient over 25%" describes Mirador del Fin del Mundo. Chris Tonge reports the Tabernas ramblas require "navigating through a maze made of sand, loose gravel, and rocks" where "you can't always rely on GPS or trail markers." Mandatory hike-a-bike sections through desert terrain demand advanced handling skills.

elevation.explanation: 52,493 feet includes the brutal opening 20km climb with 850m elevation through El Sacromonte, followed by relentless climbing to Calar Alto Observatory. Bradley Shenton realized gear mistakes on climbs "ramping up to a maximum of 25 per cent" with his 40T chainring proving inadequate. The route culminates with Europe's highest paved road at Pico Veleta.

climate.explanation: Cara Dixon reports 42°C desert temperatures nearly caused heatstroke: "Just before the climb out of the desert I had to lie down, I knew my body well enough to know that I was balancing on the edge of heat stroke." Starting at cool morning temps, the race transitions to brutal afternoon heat where riders practice "vampire racing" - hiding from sun during peak hours.

altitude.explanation: From Mediterranean sea level to 3,396m at Pico Veleta creates altitude challenges comparable to Everest base camp approaches. The final 13km climb to Hoya de la Mora closes to traffic, leaving riders alone with thin air. Overnight sections require hypothermia gear as temperatures drop from 40°C+ desert heat to near-freezing at elevation.

adventure.explanation: Chris Hall calls it "so much more than just a bike race. It's an experience with an incredible community exploring one of the most beautiful and brutal parts of Southern Spain." The route crosses three distinct desert systems, volcanic coastlines, and UNESCO Biosphere Reserves. "The views never get old," Hall notes about returning annually to the same otherworldly landscapes.

prestige.explanation: Elite riders like Mattia de Marchi, Sarah Scozzaro, and James Mark Hayden validate the field depth. "Even after riding for close to 750 km and without any sleep for the final 48 hours, I don't remember any moments of panic," de Marchi reports. The event attracts serious ultra-endurance specialists who treat it as a career-defining challenge rather than weekend adventure.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized for a self-supported ultra. GPS tracking for safety, clear rules, mandatory equipment checks. But it's intentionally minimal—you're on your own out there.

experience.explanation: James describes hitting his lowest point in La Alpujarra when "a lady came out of her house, with a tray... A jug of water, a ham and cheese sandwich and a bag of crisps... that ham and cheese sandwich quite literally saved my life." "Sleep deprivation meant I had to stop on the descent to close my eyes for 5 minutes," Claire adds about the multi-day format's toll.

community.explanation: Bradley Shenton describes Gor Village as magical: "Music is pumping, the village is out for support and Santiago is there with his trusty handycam to capture it all." Small field creates lasting connections, though the self-supported format limits rider interaction compared to supported stage races. Village support along the route provides memorable human moments.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of ~200-300 riders, attracts elite ultra-endurance athletes—bikepacking specialists, gravel racers, adventure cyclists. Not mass-participation like Unbound, but deep in ultra credentials. Winners are ultra legends. Deeper field than most — comparable to Gravel Worlds. As Pairs Strategy - Claire puts it: "We should have done some practice rides to get to know each other better, or for Simon to try sleeping in a bivi bag and packing his kit, but our only test run was a 60km cafe ride the week be..."

value.explanation: 295 EUR entry fee for 800km of marked ultra-endurance racing through unique Spanish desert terrain. The self-supported format means no included meals or accommodation, but GPS tracking, route development, and strategic support like the 24-hour Gor cafe justify costs for committed ultra riders seeking Europe's most challenging gravel experience.

expenses.explanation: Travel to Granada, specialized desert equipment, and bike setups like James's 7kg loaded bike with Tailfin bags and hydration systems create significant costs. Chris Tonge's FARA setup with SRAM Force XPLR and suspension components shows the gear investment required. Multi-day self-supported format demands extensive logistical preparation beyond the entry fee.

biased_opinion.summary: Badlands is gravel racing taken to its logical extreme. 800km, 16,000m climbing, 40°C+ deserts, 3,400m alpine passes, completely self-supported. It's not really comparable to other gravel races—it's an expedition that happens to be timed. The combination of distance, elevation, heat, and self-reliance creates something uniquely brutal. Finishing Badlands is a lifetime achievement that earns permanent respect in ultra-endurance circles.
strengths: True test of self-sufficiency and resilience
weaknesses: Extreme conditions limit who can safely attempt it
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want the ultimate test of gravel endurance, Badlands is the answer. But respect what 800km in 40°C heat actually means.

final_verdict.one_liner: The world's hardest gravel race—800km through Spanish deserts and alpine passes, completely self-supported.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you have genuine ultra-endurance experience and want the ultimate test. Yes if you can handle extreme heat and self-support logistics. Skip if you haven't completed multi-day bikepacking events or can't adapt to 40°C+ conditions.
final_verdict.alternatives: The Traka 560 (similar European ultra, less extreme); Unbound XL (350mi, supported); GB Duro (UK ultra, cooler climate)

history.origin_story: Created to be among the world's most challenging self-supported gravel events, showcasing Andalusia's extreme terrain from desert to alpine. Quickly earned reputation as the hardest gravel race on earth.
notable_moments: Established as benchmark for ultra-endurance gravel difficulty
Growing international field from ultra-endurance community
Sub-48 hour finishes by elite riders
history.reputation: The world's hardest gravel race—where ultra-endurance meets extreme conditions.

course_description.character: An 800km expedition through Andalusia's extremes. Desert badlands that look like Mars, Europe's only true desert (Tabernas), and the 3,396m Pico Veleta climb. Self-supported means you carry what you need between remote villages. The combination of distance, elevation, heat, and self-reliance is unmatched in gravel racing.

suffering_zones.label: Gorafe Desert
suffering_zones.desc: Lunar badlands terrain at 40°C+. No shade, no water, no mercy. Where the heat begins to break riders.

suffering_zones.label: Tabernas Desert
suffering_zones.desc: Europe's only true desert. Extreme heat, exposed terrain. The psychological middle-ground of suffering.

suffering_zones.label: Pico Veleta
suffering_zones.desc: 3,396m summit—highest paved road in Europe. From 40°C desert to potential freezing. The signature challenge.

suffering_zones.label: Final 200km
suffering_zones.desc: Cumulative fatigue after 3+ days. Sleep deprivation, heat damage, mechanical wear. Pure survival to the finish.

course_description.signature_challenge: The complete package—800km of desert heat, alpine altitude, and multi-day self-supported suffering through some of Europe's most extreme terrain.

A Badlands Diary | An Ultra-Endurance Ride Through Spain’s Wildest Frontier

780 kilometers. 16,000 meters of climbing. No support. No shortcuts.

This is more than a race — it’s a journey through one of Europe’s most unforgiving landscapes. In this video diary, I take you behind the handlebars as I ride across the deserts, mountains, and coastline of southern Spain in the legendary Badlands ultra-endurance event.

Filmed on the move, this is a raw and personal look at the highs, the lows, the doubts, and the moments of quiet clarity that come only after hours alone in the saddle.

Whether you're a cyclist, an adventurer, or simply curious about what it means to push your limits — welcome to my Badlands.

🔔 Don't forget to SUBSCRIBE and hit the bell icon to follow my ultra gravel challenge preparation and more cycling adventures!: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCDOH8kjK1Xio7cCShNFbFHQ?sub_confirmation=1

Badlands is a ultra distance race in Spain in the only desert in Europe - it's 800k with 16,000m of elevation. There's definitely going to be testing times, it's such a long time and you don't really know until you're in it when it's going to pick you up or push you down.

key_challenges.name: Climb after Tabernas
key_challenges.description: 14km climb with 1,100m elevation gain that comes after 350km of riding. Riders report knee pain starting on this climb.

key_challenges.name: First 300km
key_challenges.description: Basically one big climb with first 1,000 meters of climbing in just 28 kilometers. Sets the tone for massive elevation early in the race.

key_challenges.name: Coast to mountain transition
key_challenges.description: After reaching the coast, riders face 3 hours of climbing up a rock garden to get back up from sea level.

key_challenges.name: Night riding at altitude
key_challenges.description: Mental battle when it's dark and you can't see what's coming. Riders report nearly falling asleep and having to rest at 2,000m elevation where it's freezing.

terrain_notes.text: Desert section with rivets in the ground that can catch bike wheels and cause crashes. Surface feels twisty and technical.
80km of desert riding through the Tabernas desert that's dramatic and breathtaking, with temperatures reaching 46°C.
Rock garden climbing sections that require sustained technical effort for hours.

gear_mentions.text: Riders recommend adding extra electrolytes, specifically 1500mg tubes, due to high heat. Plan for 35+ hours worth of fuel and don't rely solely on picking up food.

race_day_tips.text: Start deliberately slow, keep heart rate down, and ease into it since it's such a long day. Resist urge to go faster early on.
Plan nutrition strategy with 90g carbs per hour for first part, then settle into sustainable pacing. Carry enough to be self-sufficient for first 24 hours.
When falling asleep while riding, take a 30-minute rest even in poor conditions rather than risk crashing.

The Ultra community is unlike any other in cycling. While it's 800 kilometers of brutal terrain, the race feels remarkably accessible. It's not dominated by aero obsessed riders in skin suits chasing marginal gains. Instead, there's a mix of everyday cyclists, first timers, and people who like me just had the aim to finish. It felt inclusive, warm, and supportive.

rider_intel.search_text: Badlands is an 800km ultra-distance race through southern Spain's diverse terrain including the Tabernas desert, Europe's only desert. The route features massive early climbing with the first 300km being essentially one big climb, starting with 1,000m elevation gain in just 28km. Key challenges include a brutal 14km climb with 1,100m gain after Tabernas at mile 217, night riding at 2,000m altitude in freezing conditions, and a 3-hour rock garden climb from the coast back to the mountains. The desert section spans 80km with temperatures reaching 46°C and technical terrain with rivets that can catch wheels. Riders emphasize the inclusive ultra community atmosphere and recommend starting conservatively, carrying 35+ hours of fuel, extra electrolytes for heat, and planning 90g carbs per hour initially. The route covers dramatic landscape variety from desert to forest to coastal roads.
